summary: The document details an investigation into the tampering with Kennedy autopsy photos by Regis Blahut, a CIA employee, discovered in a safe within the House Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA) offices. It includes the process of fingerprint analysis that identified Blahut's involvement, the subsequent security measures implemented, and the CIA's internal investigation which included polygraph tests of Blahut.
key_findings: Evidence of tampering with Kennedy autopsy photos was discovered, with specific photos (39E1, 39E2, 40E, and 41E) being removed from their binders.
Fingerprint analysis linked Regis Blahut, a CIA employee, to the tampering, with his prints found on the inside of the safe door and on one of the photos.
The document details the investigative process, including the collection and analysis of latent prints, and the involvement of the Metropolitan Police Identification section.
The CIA conducted its own investigation, including polygraph tests of Blahut, who admitted to lying about his involvement but maintained his actions were not malicious.
Discovery of tampered Kennedy autopsy photos in safe #102095.
Identification of Regis Blahut's fingerprints on the safe door and photo 39E2.
Implementation of stricter security measures for the JFK safe, including locking it at all times.
The involvement of multiple committee staff and CIA personnel in the incident.
